sub_title: Food and Health Project Developer & Director | Certified Brain Health Professional | Functional Medicine Certified Health Coach
summary:
Director and project developer on strategic and operating studies on food, health, environment and sustainability of a private-sector company, Glen Eastman Food & Health Limited.

I'm a Functional Medicine Certified Health Coach trained on leading, guiding, informing and educating clients on health by supporting and motivating lifestyle change using positive psychology.

I'm an Amen Clinics Certified Brain Health Professional.

I completed a Ph.D. on understanding the physics emerging when an ultra-intense laser pulse interacts with solid materials. Over this project I manage and delegate the work. This involves conducting experimental measurements at national laboratories. I develop 3D CAD drawings with Autodesk Inventor for experimental components to engineer. For data analysis I develop and apply Python and Matlab codes for concise interpretation of the results. In order to understand the results I link these to theoretical predictions as well as computational models using large-scale computer clusters.

For my interests I am a music composer as well as play guitar, piano, taiko, shinobue, shakuhachi and percussion. I am a health-focused whole-foods cook, sustainability advocate especially for agri-food systems, skilful photographer, lifelong learner, outdoor attic, and interested in language and culture.

awards.title: The York Award
awards.description:
As printed on certificate:
"The York Award is a programme of personal and skills development offered by the University of York in partnership with leading public, private and voluntary sector organisations. The York Award certificate is awarded alongside the degree in recognition of achievement of a significant programme of activity and, in particular, the adoption of an analytical and reflective approach to learning and competence in a broad range of skills."​

Recognised as a unique graduate for completing a specialised and distinctive Summer Placement at the York Plasma Institute, publishing a personal experience profile at the University's Careers Service website.

projects.title: Anisotropy measurements of resistive plasmas for investigating the microphysics of warm dense matter
projects.description:
Experimental team: Christopher Baird, Nicola Booth (PI), Leonard Döhl (Target Area Operator), Damon Farley, James Green, Shih-Ming He, Robert Heathcote, Yasuhiro Kuramitsu, Kate Lancaster, Chris Murphy, John Pasley, Will Trickey and Nigel Woolsey.

Primary objective was to probe for the plasma resistivity in low temperature plasma regime of <200 eV. This was achieved by measuring polarised spectral X-ray emission from a warm dense plasma generated using the Vulcan Petawatt Laser. This was achieved by studying the impact of the laser parameters when irradiating polysulphone micro-foils.

A secondary objective to the experiment was to test laser-driven ion acceleration using ultra-thin graphene foils by measuring the energy spectrum using radiographic imaging and solid state nuclear track detectors. By using a range of target thicknesses by effectively stacking individual graphene foils we probed for a range of proton and carbon ion energies distributions.

contributors.headline: Food and Health Project Developer & Director | Certified Brain Health Professional | Functional Medicine Certified Health Coach

projects.title: Modelling high-intensity laser-solid interactions on ultra-thin graphene films
projects.description:
9-week independent project-led research at the National Central University (Taiwan) and Osaka University (Japan) with Rajesh Dhiman, Yuji Fukuda, Yasuhiro Kuramitsu, Christopher Ridgers, Youichi Sakawa and Nigel Woolsey. This project received funding from the internal collaboratory budget of the Fusion Centre for Doctoral Training program, University of York.

This project is an independent and personal project conducted upon the acceptance of a successful project proposal, project plan, risk assessment and agreement with the institutes. The tasks in this laboratory astrophysics research area were to investigate the laser-based particle acceleration schemes achievable through laser wakefield acceleration in the bubble regime and ion acceleration using ultra-thin graphene film, as well as the formation of collisionless Weibel instabilities. The primary objective, on which the budget and final project deliveries of a report and presentation were focused on, was on EPOCH particle-in-cell modelling of the graphene as target materials for laser-driven ion acceleration.

This project was an opportunity to expand and develop on academic and research skills in an international and interdisciplinary context. My knowledge of the EPOCH particle-in-cell code led to me leading a short lecture-style workshop on using the simulation tool to master students at the National Central University. The project extended into my PhD as a new research area and me becoming a leading collaborator of the continuation of the work.

projects.title: Laser-driven acceleration by microstructures silicon targets
projects.description:
Additional members: Christopher Baird, Gabriel Schaumann, Robert Heathcote, Christopher Spindloe, Aasia Hughes and CLF staff.

Experiment at Vulcan Target Area Petawatt, Central Laser Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory.

Research has suggested that microstructures surfaces of similar size to the laser wavelength can enhance the laser energy absorption and generate denser and hotter electrons and ions. In the experiment we induce flat and needled silicon foils with an ultra-intense, high-contrast laser pulse to observe this phenomenon. To diagnose we studied the reflected laser intensity, X-ray spectra, and angular and energy distributions of electrons and ions to characterize the emission and validate the enhanced laser absorption.

Affiliations: Technische Universität Darmstadt, Germany; Science and Technology Facility Council, UK; University of Strathclyde, UK; University of York, UK.

contributors.headline: Food and Health Project Developer & Director | Certified Brain Health Professional | Functional Medicine Certified Health Coach

projects.title: Extreme X-ray radiation fields created during an ultra-intense laser-solid interaction
projects.description:
Additional members: Luca Labate, Leo Gizzi, Chris Spindloe, Anatoly Faenov, Nicola Booth, James Green and Christopher Ridgers.

Experiment at Vulcan Target Area West, Central Laser Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory.

The objective was to investigate X-ray radiation fields emerging when an ultra-intense and high-contrast picosecond laser pulse is interacting with a low-Z, micro-thin foil at solid-density. This laser-solid interaction creating the radiation field is radiation dominated and suggested to emerge via nonlinear Thomson scattering and Bremsstrahlung. We studied this X-ray field using focusing spectrometers with high spatial resolution and radiochromic film to characterise the emission to target thickness, composition and micro-structured topography as well as the laser intensity, contrast and induced energy.

projects.title: Laboratory Simulation of Magnetized Plasma Turbulence in the Intergalactic Medium
projects.description:
Laboratory astrophysics experiment at Vulcan Target Area West, Central Laser Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory.

The experiment focused on recreating magnetic amplification observed in intergalactic medium of galaxies in the laboratory. The work was conducted using the long-pulse laser beams of the Vulcan laser to bombard plastic foils. The bombardment ablates the foils and shots two plasma jets. The jets are magnetized and interact with a mesh grid to transmit magnetic shock waves from opposite directions onto each other for a head-on collision. The collisions amplify the carried magnetic field which replicate astrophysical turbulent systems near the vicinity of supermassive black holes at the centre of galaxies. The amplification and shock waves is also believed to drive charged particles to highly relativistic energies comparable to cosmic rays, specifically protons in the experiment. The mechanism for the acceleration is described by second-order Fermi acceleration.

Principle Investigator was Prof Gianluca Gregori, University of Oxford
The group leader of the experiment was Dr Thomas White (Target Area Operator), University of Oxford.
The team consisted of Paul Mabey (Deputy Target Area Operator, University of Oxford), Matthew Oliver (Oxford), Marina Kühn-Kauffeldt (Universität der Bundeswehr München) and Leonard Döhl (University of York).
Supporters include Robert Heathcote, Youichi Sakawa, Michel Koenig and the CLF staff.

profile_positions.title: Director and Entrepreneur

profile_positions.description: Strategic and operating studies on biomass, hydrogen and nuclear fusion.
profile_positions.title: Scientific Expert on New Energy and Environmental Protection

profile_positions.description:
My PhD project focuses on understanding the physics emerging when an ultra-intense laser pulse interacts with solid materials. This involves conducting and managing experimental investigations at national laboratories, such as the Vulcan Petawatt Laser at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory (UK), in a team and as a team leader. The project has two primary objectives: interpreting the impact of enhanced laser absorption using surface micro-structured silicon targets using X-ray and electron spectroscopy; and development of laser-driven high-energy carbon ion sources using ultra-thin graphene foils and ion radiography and spectroscopy. 

Over the course of the project I have co-led experiments at national laboratories and managed my independent computational project abroad with the completion of a successful project proposal and close-up report. I am trained on experimental techniques using sophisticated imaging, alignment and spectroscopic techniques. I successfully completed many experiments in interdisciplinary and international teams. Furthermore I apply EPOCH particle-in-cell simulations as well as atomic modelling on FLYCHK and PrismSPECT codes in order to interpret the physics in experiments. For concise data analysis and diagnostic modelling I develop and apply my own Python and Matlab codes. I present my work at international conferences and institute visits, while networking and leading discussions onsite and via electronic communication.

My project is part of a collaboration communicating with institutes in UK, Germany, USA, Russia, Taiwan and Japan. This work is funded by the Central Laser Facility, Science Technology Facility Council and the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council Centre for Doctoral Training.

Amongst extra-curriculum I am a Postgraduate Teaching Assistant supporting undergraduate teaching in the Department of Physics. My role involves leading problem classes, lab demonstrator and assessing student work.
profile_positions.title: Fusion Centre for Doctoral Training, EPSRC PhD in Plasma Science and Fusion Energy

profile_positions.description:
Online tuition in Mathematics and Physics for GCSE and A-level students.

As an online tutor I tailor the lessons according to the students needs. The lessons revise course material, enhance further learning and prepare for examinations.

Flexible lessons are provided according to both my and the student's availability. The lessons require prepared organisation and consistent management throughout. The teaching qualities developed on enhanced my communication skills in explaining information consistently.

Work with the Sales Team for the 'Meet Your Tutor' sessions since April 2014 (first trial). These sessions enable students and their parents/guardians to test whether they would benefit from online lessons. The sessions introduce Maths Doctor and demonstrate how online tuition works, using an online dialler for telecommunication.
profile_positions.title: Online Tutor

profile_positions.description:
Summer Work Experience in experimental and theoretical research at the York Plasma Institute (YPI) and the York Plasma Institute Laboratory at the University of York, York.

The work is tailored to my final year Master of Physics research project which is the study of the extreme x-ray radiation field generated by an ultra-intense laser beam. The research investigates the radiation field and its exotic properties. The project involves studying computational simulations with EPOCH PIC code and Geant4, cooperate in a team at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory and use the Vulcan Petawatt Laser facility for the radiation field investigation, and program (a) spectral analysis code(s) to estimate the experimental radiation spectra and intensities, comparing it to the simulations.

In a research team at the Vulcan Petawatt Laser facility we anticipate to acquire experimental data of the radiation field. Personal tasks have involved preparing, acquiring and testing diagnostics, equipment and accessories, and processing and analysing experimental data.

The project is supervised by N. Woolsey.
Collaborators: E. Tubman, P. Durey, C. Ridgers, C. Barton, P. Davies, R. Crowston, R. Loetzsch, S. Pikuz, A. Faenov, N. Butler, R. Dance, P. McKenna, J. Green, N. Booth, R. Clarke, J. Suarez, T. Winstone, M. Galimberti, I. Musgrave, D. Pepler, S. Crisp, A. Cox, D. Wyatt, C. Spindloe, C. Gregory.
profile_positions.title: Summer Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Summer Work Experience in experimental and theoretical research at the York Plasma Institute (YPI) and the York Plasma Institute Laboratory at the University of York, York.

My work was supervised by Dr Nigel Woolsey and his current graduate students, Rachel Dance, Eleanor Tubman and Robert Crowston.

I researched the experimental uses of CCD detectors for x-ray radiation and the study of single photon counting in the x-ray region, from published articles and University literature. Experimental work was in a laser hazard zone, for which I became a registered laser user and underwent laser safety training. Used an Andors Classic DX440-BN in a vacuum chamber, imaging x-rays from target interaction with class 4 laser pulses. I employed alignment lasers of class 3B for building optical paths between target to detectors and plasma diagnostic tools. I programmed Python and Matlab codes for the single photon counting analysis, where the Matlab code evaluated the ideal filter thicknesses for peak detection of spectral x-rays from target. The python code evaluated the analysis to determine the temperature at laser-target interaction point, with the aid of importing data through ImageJ.

Furthermore, I worked with Ocean Optic HR2000+ Spectrometer to record Argon gas spectra and compared data against Argon data from the NIST database. The analysis indicated that spectral and intensity calibrations were required. Independently, I used a HG-1 Light calibration source for spectral calibration to reset the wavelength calibration coefficients of the spectrometer using Python coding with the linear regression method to determine the coefficients. I employed a LS-1-CAL-220 calibration source to install an absolute irradiance reading to the spectrometer's memory chip to process and measure intensity in physical units for the intensity calibration. A document about the calibration procedure for future post doctoral training was written.
profile_positions.title: Summer Worker

profile_positions.description:
Working for the York Careers Service at the University of York as an York Student In Schools (YSIS) Student Tutor for York College.

My position involved providing assistant in teaching in physics to GCSE (Sixth Form) students for 7 sessions (2 hours each session per week minimum). The classes were of ~14 pupils, and the sessions included problem solving and practical experiments within the teaching hours of the teacher. My work contributed to the College involved the preparation of the experimental apparatus, explain the physics behind the experiments and problems, and the thinking behind approaching physics questions.

The skills developed through the experience were communication between the teachers and the students, self-management, time management, organisation and flexibility.

The teachers I assisted were J. Burr, M. Clark, M. Steven and R. Hodgson
profile_positions.title: York Students In Schools Student Tutor

volunteer_experiences.description:
Volunteering opportunity for Science students, which became interlinked with Physics Outreach at the University of York in early October 2013 through Katherine Leech, Outreach Officer at the Department of Physics.

The position involves legal participation in Science Outreach events organised by STEMNET, external organisations or the Physics Department's Outreach Officer. The events are various between Family Fun with Science, School Day Events and Public Events.

The Events have various demonstrations in Astronomy and Physics, providing physical insight and fun activities.

Volunteering for the Yorkshire Museum Trust in the York Observatory located in the Museum Garden, York. The dates of volunteering are selected by the volunteers themselves on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday, from 11:30 to 14:30, all year.

The position involves opening the York Observatory to the public, allowing them to see the Observatory, read about the history of the Observatory, see the Observatory's refractor telescope constructed by Thomas Cooke & Son, and enjoy the use of astronomical programs such as Stellarium. Visitors can come in for free, always ask questions and leave any remarks/feedback.

The number of visitors are registered to keep a record for the York Observatory and the Yorkshire Museum Trust.

volunteer_experiences.role: UCAS Open Days Student Guide (Department of Physics)
volunteer_experiences.description:
Paid volunteering opportunity for the Department of Physics at the University of York. The opportunity only runs during Autumn and Spring term in the academic semesters on a Thursday from 10:15 to 16:15.

The position involves representing the University to UCAS student applicants, who received an invitation to an interview and are considered to join the University the next academic year. As the student guide, it is vital to present the Department and University to the applicants and/or applicant's parents.

The duties include running a set program for the day (e.g. show and describe various facilities on the campus and the department, bring applicants to the academic staff that will be interviewing each individual, present the astrocampus, and tell applicants about student life in both the course and social aspects).

Professional skills that were developed include self-management (particularly time-management), communication (cooperation with other guides and staff, applicants and their parents) and teamwork.

Outreach opportunity through the Institute of Physics at St. Olave High School, York.

This public event involved giving demonstration of general physical phenomena to inspire the public about physics. The public could also engage in the phenomena by attending to reproduce them after a demonstration.

The demonstration included were a standing wave showing resonance, a balloon with a stick, air-water pressure with a glass sealed by a card, contact friction between two books stacked between their pages, causing water in a copper bowl to vibrate through simple hand motion on the bowl handles and more.

Developed in teamwork, communication and social awareness with the public.
